Comment.val: /* If set, this will be the default tab folder for the Address Book */

Text.val: This is an example of a parameter. If this program was called from another program, it would
set the default value for the Tab variable below, via an Init.
This is an example of a virtual. In this case it is going to act as a filter for the data.
These are examples of Column variables. They are selected from the Main Table. If we had a Linked
table, they could also be selected from that.
The View Refresh forces the range to reset and the records to be reloaded
when the user changes the tab choice.

Text.valUnicode: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;\red255\green0\blue128;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.15.1515;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\cf1\b\f0\fs20 Task variables in Magic are very easy to create. \par \par There are only a few basic datatypes, which might be confusing at first if you are used to lower-level languages. However, the translation to bit-level coding is generally handled automatically, and can be specified exactly when needed.\par \par The three basic variable types in Magic are:\par \par 1. \cf2 Parameters\cf1 : variables that can be passed in or out\par \par 2. \cf2 Virtuals\cf1 : Local variables\par \par 3. \cf2 Columns\cf1 : Fields in a data source (either the Main or Linked tables).\par \par This example shows all three.\par }

ExpSyntax.val: 'DV05: How Do I Define Task Variables?'

Text.val: This task writes to two text BLOBS, then reads them into a memory table.
This reads in the blob, using a ':' as a delimiter
